thread.title: Former Red Sox teammates Jon Lester and John Lackey put friendship on hold in MLB playoffs
thread.title_full: Former Red Sox teammates Jon Lester and John Lackey put friendship on hold in MLB playoffs

title: Former Red Sox teammates Jon Lester and John Lackey put friendship on hold in MLB playoffs
text: AP Sports Writer | 10.09.15 | 8:00 AM ST. LOUIS (AP) — John Lackey has been quite the bargain for the St. Louis Cardinals. Pitching for the major league minimum $507,500 salary due to a clause in contract, Lackey went 13-10 for a team that lost its ace early. And when old rivals face each other in a postseason series for the first time Friday, he’ll be pitching against an old buddy. Advertisement - Continue Reading Below The 36-year-old Lackey will oppose the Chicago Cubs’ Jon Lester, a duo that formed a devastating one-two for the Red Sox in the 2013 World Series. ‘‘I’d like to say I was surprised, but I’m not,’’ Lackey said Thursday. ‘‘He’s good. No accident people running into each other this time of year.’’ Lackey had a career-best 2.77 ERA and consistently went deep for the 100-win Cardinals, stepping up as the de facto ace after Adam Wainwright tore his left Achilles in late April. He has earned this slot, the crusty, bulldog demeanor reminding management of former star pitcher Chris Carpenter. Lackey was paid $82.5 million the previous five years under a contract he signed with Boston, which included a conditional club option for 2015 at the minimum. That condition was met when he missed 2012 while recovering from reconstructive elbow surgery. St. Louis acquired him from the Red Sox on July 31, 2014. Lackey can become a free agent again this fall. ‘‘I don’t think we’ll discuss what we’re doing in the offseason or strategy in the offseason at this point,’’ Cardinals general manager John Mozeliak said. ‘‘We’re excited he’s a part of it and we’re looking forward to a successful October.’’ Lester and Lackey combined for three victories in a six-game 2013 Series triumph over the Cardinals. Lester was 2-0 with a 0.59 ERA and Lackey won the clincher. ‘‘He was probably the best on the planet going through the playoffs that year,’’ Lackey said. ‘‘He knows how to compete and he knows how to handle this time of year, for sure.’’ Lester will try to follow an excellent wild-card performance by Jake Arrieta, who threw a four-hitter Wednesday night in a 4-0 victory over the Pirates. Lester figured he’d be matched against 17-game winner Michael Wacha, but the right-hander was 2-3 with a 7.78 ERA the final month and will start Game 3. When Lester learned he would be opposed by Lackey, he thought it funny — and fitting. ‘‘He’s going to almost out-will you sometimes, if that makes sense,’’ Lester said. ‘‘Our friendship will go beyond this game, will go beyond this career, but come tomorrow, we’re not buddies anymore.’’ STORY CONTINUES BELOW GALLERY Previous -- of -- Next Pedro Martinez is the most recent Red Sox player to join the Hall of Fame. He played for the Sox from 1998 until 2004, when they won the World Series for the first time in 86 years. Martinez had a total of 3,154 career strikeouts upon retiring in 2009. The Boston Globe/Jim Davis Previous -- of -- Next Jim Rice was a staple in left field for the Red Sox for most of his 15-year career. In 1978 he was named the American League’s Most Valuable Player. By the time he retired in 1989, he had been an eight-time All-Star. He was inducted into the Hall of Fame in 2009. The Boston Globe/Jan Housewerth Wade Boggs played 11 seasons with Boston. Known best for his hitting, Boggs won five batting titles during his time in Boston. He was inducted to the Hall of Fame in 2005, six years after retiring. AP Photo Previous -- of -- Next Carl “Yaz” Yastrzemski spent his entire 23-year career in Boston. He took over in left field for the great Ted Williams in 1961, making it to his first All-Star game two seasons later. Yastrzemski was inducted in 1989, six years after retiring.
